fol.195v
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
& one of her Hig
nes
most honorable privy councel.
31 May 1585 From M
r
Bodeley
fol.190r
Right honorable, my humble duty to yo
r
H. most affectionatly
remembred, from
Hambourgh
I writte a former, the 7 of this p
nt
:
& had since no opportunitie to send any other, till my comminge
His arryvall at
Lubecke
.
nowe to Lubecke. W
t
in 6 daies after I sent yow my former, I
came to
Wolferbeitel
, a towne not farre from
Brunswicke
, where
most commonly
e
Duke
doth make his aboade: who advertised
of my comminge, sent unto me to mine Inne 3 of his councel:
Otto Van Heim
,
D
r
Usler
&
Lieutenant Ive
, & divers gentlemen
besides, that came in their company, w
t
a scoare of his garde, &
his owne horse litter. Assoone as they were entered, & all had
Conference w
th
cer-
taine of
e Duke
of Brunswick
Councell./
bid me welcome, D
r
Usler in Latin beganne to shew me from the Duke
how earnestly he longed, to heare me tell him somwhat of her Ma
tie
of her prosperous welfare, & of the quietnes of her countrey, and
happines in all thinges: & used unto me a very harty gratula-
tion for my safe arrival, w
t
many courtesies & offers in
e name
of the Duke, w
c
to specifie in particular w
t
mine answeare
againe, would be altogether tedious. Our speches beinge
ended, I was conducted by them all to
Francis Mutzettin
the Chauncello
rs
house, who went that morninge towardes
Breame
And there I was lodged by the Dukes appointment, had my diet
from
e Dukes kitchin, was served by his gentlemen & officers,
and had alwaies at my meales the company of his councel:
whoe did me continually certaine honorable services, of whiche
& of other particularities not material to my message, I reserve
the relation at yo
r
H pleasure & leasure, when I come into
Englande
.
Two daies after I was lodged, suche of the Councel, as I named
before, & two others besides
D. Farembelt
&
M
r
Statius
, came by
times in a morning to my chamber, where D. Usler, who was com-
monly their speaker, signified unto me that
e Duke was merve-
lous desirous, to have had me come to him, & to communicat w
t
me
He delivered his
message to
certaine of
e Councell
by reason of
e Duke his indisposition./
about divers matters, but he was so exceedingly troubled w
t
e
goute,
e palsey,
e stone, & all at that instant, as it was pain-
full unto him, to speake or to be spoken unto. Wheruppon
e Duke
earnestly praied me, whatsoever it was I had to deliver, I would
deale w
t
his councel, as if himself were present, promising suche
dispatche as the affaires did require. Wherunto I made answer
that as I was desirous, & expressely commaunded to impart her
Ma
ties
salutacons, & her singular affection, & all the rest of mine
errande to the Duke himself in person: so it grieved me greatly
fol.190v
to carie home to her Hig
nes
those sorowfull tidinges of his weake dis-
position. Howbeit for that
my
buisnes was of moment & required
no delay, not douting but their wisdomes would deale thereafter in
it, if it pleased them presently to geve me mine audience, I
would not willingly differ it. Wheruppon & some other like spee-
ches that passed betwixt us, & having gone too & fro betweene
e
D. & me, & considered of my letters, they all at last came in to-
gether, w
t
inke & paper in their handes, & praied me to tell theme
what I had further to intreat of, then was expressed in
e letters
whiche while I uttered unto them to that effect as I was willed
by her Ma
ties
instructions, they did all of them write what I said
& some me thought so fast, as they noted every worde: whiche I
take to be their custome in causes of importaunce: But my letters
to the Electo
r
s &
e
Lant
.
of Hesse
, they requested me to kepe,
till they had spoken w
t
e Duke: Usinge many good wordes in
commendation of her Ma
tie
her forwardnes & zele in advaun-
cing these causes: but desired my patience, if I taried longer
for an answear then perhaps I expected: because my petitions
were many, & the D. in health so ill disposed.
Uppon my daily solicitinge, the 23. of this present, every one of
the councel came againe to my chamber: where D. Usler deli-
vered the D. resolution. First in the D. behalf he used wordes
of gratulation, for her Ma
ties
prosperitie w
c
I had signified
unto him, & the happie estate of her contrey. & then thanked her
High
nes
for so kinde a message, w
t
protestation againe of like
harty good will, whiche he dilated very muche. Lastly com-
ming to the matter, yelded in every thing, to perfourme her M
ties
The said Duke
willing to accomplishe
her Ma
ts
request in
all poynt
requestes, as farre as lay in his power: to sende her letters to
e
Electo
r
s &
e Lantgrave, to joine his owne unto them, to move
them to a diet, and a generall union, aswell of forces as of min-
des, & to come themselves in person, or to send their deputies,
w
t
full autoritie to conclude: In particular to consider of some
succo
r
to the
kinge of Navarra
, to take order w
t
his churchemen
to deale w
t
more charitie, to hinder both
e levieng &
e passage
of souldiers, & to give in conclusion his uttermost furtheraunce
Howbeit for the diet, he was of opinion that it would not be so soone,
That the Convention
cannot be so soone
as her Ma
ty
desireth./
as
e cause doth require, & her Ma
tie
desireth: for that
it
if
chiefly
consisteth in the Princes Electors, who he douted would have time,
to determine suche a matter. Notw
t
standing for his owne part
there should want no solicitinge: & besides in the circle
fol.191r
The session to
be kept at
Hal-
berstat
e 17 of
July next./
of the
lowe
Princes of the Lowe Saxonie
, whiche is kept at Halberstat
the 17 of July next ensewinge, he himself would propose & folowe
the whole matter. And therein the better to effectuat his purpose,
he would send his Embassado
rs
, out of hand to
e
Administrato
r
That he wold send to
e administrator of
Halles: & in
e
meane tyme stay
e Levy of Soldiers
[fo
r
]
e
D. of Guise
./
of Halles who is chief in that meetinge. In
e mean season he
had already at home done his best endevo
r
for the stainge of suche
souldiers, as were ether to be levied, or to passe out of his contrey
and in witnes therof offered unto me suche edictes as he had pub-
lished, w
c
I send yo
r
H. w
t
my letter. Moereover for as muche
as her Ma
tie
did not send me to the Electo
r
s, whiche he thought
had bin expedient, to excuse this matter the better, he would
consaile me as of my self, to write to
e
D. of Saxonie
, & to
signifie what caused that her Ma
tie
sent not to him, whiche letter
he promised to send w
t
his owne. For that he had besides to im-
That M
r
Bodley shold
r
eturne that waye
sou
th for answeare to
his l
re
s written to
e
D. of Saxony,
and
or other matter of im-
portance to be com-
municated to him./
part somwhat unto me of speciall importaunce, he was very de-
sirous that returninge out of
Denmarke
, I should repaire
againe to him, & receave
e Electors aunswears. In the meane
while, he thought it not amisse, that I sent some messenger into
England to declare howe farre I had proceeded. And lastly
to my self he made an offer of all his favo
r
s, if I needed
him in any thing: & so made an ende w
t
e D. good wishes to
my voiage, thankes for my travaile in this cause, & for my pa-
tience there &c.
In mine answear hereunto, for those affectionat speeches, courtesies
and compliments whiche were uttered at first, there was nothing
omitted that was to be replied in her Ma
ties
behalf: especially
in declaring what contentment she would take, to see her expec-
tation so satisfied in every thing demaunded: whiche I was
willing should be knowen so soone as was possible, & therfor
would if he desired it, send a messenger expressly. Nevertheles
for that nothing as yet was done in dede & effectually, & be-
cause it was my meaninge at Lubecke, where I might have
conveiaunce, to write of all at length, I thought a messenger might
be spared, unles the D. should thinke otherwise. Againe whereas
he thought it behoofull, for the better satisfaction of
e D. of Saxonie
that I should make her Ma
ties
excuse in a letter from my self:
the truth was so, that as a privat person I durst not be so bold,
and as sent by her Ma
tie
my commission would not beare it.
Nevertheles whatsoever I should doe directed by his wisdome, I
did not any way make dout, but her Ma
tie
would like it. And
therfor
fol.191v
He writt his privat
L
re
to
e Electo
r
of
Saxonye./
therfor for my letter, it should be written out of hande, & left to
his good pleasure to send it or otherwise. Therew
t
all I offered my
service into Denmarke, if he had cause to use me, yelded thankes
for mine intertenment, w
t
certaine speeches to the councel: who,
when I had ended signified unto me, that seing I intended to write
into England, there neded no messenger to be purposly sent. But
for my letter to the Electo
r
, the Duke did wishe me to write it, &
he would send it w
t
his owne. W
t
all otto van Heim tooke me
a part, & tolde me in my ear
r
e, that
e D. would have me in
any wise to endite my letter w
t
out attributing any thinge to him,
but making as if her Ma
ties
trust were chiefly in Saxonie. This
letter being written was caried to
e Duke, who sent me backe
worde that he liked it well, & desired a copie: as I have in-
serted heere an other, nothing douting but her Ma
tie
being privy to
the circumstaunce will account it no presumption.
The Copy of M
r
Bodleys l
re
to
e
Electo
r
of Sax
.
Illustriss
me
ac potentiss. Princeps, quod ad Cels. V
am
meas
do literas, audacius fit omni no quam humilitatem meam
decet: sed dedit hac audaci
ae
cum illius Vestr
ae
perinsignis
fiducia bonitatis, tum illa singularis inter serenissimam
Reginam Angli
ae
at
Cels. V
am
benevolenti
ae
coniunctio. Equi-
dem in mandatis habui proximis superioribus diebus, ut su
ae
Regi
ae
Ma
tis
literas cum ad sereniss
m
Regem Dani
ae
, tum ad
Illustriss
m
Ducem Brunsuicensem perferrem: quas autem &
ad Cels. V
am
& ad Illustriss.
Electorem Brandeburgensem
at
Hassi
ae
Lantgravium perscripserat, ut earum tradendar[.]
Illustriss
mo
Ducj Brunsuicensj curam relinguerem. Inu-
sitate quidem istue & gravate prorsus fecit, ut in huiuscemod[iis]
negotijs pr
ae
sertim tanti momentj, vicariam cuius fidem sap-
poneret, cum ut conveniat, & talia quidem soleat per nunnios
conficere. Veruntamen quia Brunsuicum abest non procul ab
itinere in Daniam, & quia res est eius generis ac profecto magni-
tudinis, ut ad eam expediendam, sit idem, propemodam, non adhi
bere celeritatem & rem totam negligere, pertinet ad illam vestra[m]
pr
ae
cellentem prudentiam, & vero etiam ad illum anim
u
pro-
pensissimum, quem in similibus negotijs & serenissma Regina
& communis Christiana rei causa est experta non servet, non
solum
fol.192
solum talem literarum missionem boni consulere, sed & ita etiam
probare c
ae
teris Principibus, ut eam omnes coniuncte, & pro sua sin-
gulj parte benevole accipiant. Iam diu est Princeps Illustriss
me
cum apud nostros ita loquimur, Ex multis pr
ae
cluriss
mis
patro-
nis at
defensoribus Christiani nominis, neminem nos habere
ad civis opem, autoritatem, gratiam fidentius confugere quam
ad vestram possineus. Hic igit
r
spero faciet Celsitudo V
ae
&
dabit mihi hanc Veniam ut suas sapientissimas cogitationis mius
literis interpellem, & hoc quidem totum de muncis non mittendo,
benigne interpretabit
r
. Interea quidem ut Cels. V
ae
perpetuo
bene sit, & ab opt. Deo suppliciter contendo, & futuram sane pro
sua mirifica in Rempub. Evangelicam
charitate
confido.
My letter thus written, and their answear receaved, I made my
sute to be dismissed, & to have a copie w
t
me of the D. letters to
the Electors &
e Lantgrave: whiche were not written as then,
but
e next daye after, I was promised to have them & so to
[Th]e said Duke will wrytt
more roundly to
e
Electo
rs
&
e Lantgrave
[.] uppon his first l
re
s
they shewe not them-
[s]elves forwarde in
e
[c]ause./
depart. The letters were written in Dutche, and the same to
them all, as I have herein sent the copie. And if uppon this first
they shewe themselves backward, or not so forward as is nedefull,
then the Duke is purposed, to write more roundly in the next, &
to persuade them more directly to her Ma
ties
course: whiche to doe
nowe at first, he thought would hinder more then further. For I
was tolde very flatly by divers of his councel, that Saxonie in
The D. of Sax
.
is
especially to be dealt
w
th
all.
special must be dealth w
t
all in this w
t
singuler dexteritie.
For in dede he ruleth all, & would have it so reputed: and unles
he be estemed the autor & contriver of every good enterprise, he
will quickly fall to gelousie, & take a sinister opinion.
The D. letter receaved, & leave obtened to depart, the D. sent me
a coache for my self, & an other for my men, to Bringe us to Bruns
wicke, willinge Otto Van Heim, & an other gentleman to kepe me
company, & to bringe us to be lodged in the house of the
Abbot of
Ridaghusen
fast by Brunsw
.
to whom he sent before hande to
make o
r
provision.
Being
The Abbote being letted sent presently
to Brunsw
.
to have us there intertened at his owne cost & charge:
Where I was also presented w
t
many pottes of wine by
e magistrates
of the cittie, who sent their sergeaunts w
t
their secretarie to offer
it, w
t
certaine gratulatarie speeches accordinge to their custome.
The next daye after I departed towardes Lubecke, where I came
in safetie 2 daies since, & nowe expect but a winde to passe
fol.192v
for
Coppenhaven
.
Nowe to impart mine owne opinion to yo
r
H. w
t
suche particular ob-
servations as seme to be material, & concerne my present service,
albeit it make longe letter, yet I thought it pertinent for per-
fourmaunce of my duty. In the D. of Brunsw
.
court whiche I
thought almost impossible, I could talke w
t
no man in a maner, I
meane of his councell aswel as the rest, that of the trobles in
Fraunce
could tell me more then this, that
e Guise was in armes,
but of any other circumstaunce, as what he pretendeth, who hath joined
w
t
him, howe farre he hath proceeded, what forces he hath gathered, they
were as ignorant as might be. For whiche I gave them a copie
of the
Cardinal of Barbons
declaration, a note of suche advertis-
ments as I receaved of yo
r
H. & the copie of a letter w
c
was
sent from
e K. of Navarra to
Mons
r
de la Fontaine
, & he de-
livered it to me, when I was ready to depart. These occurrences
were imparted w
t
e Duke, to whome they were welcome, and
many copies taken, w
c
he sent the Electors, the Administrator of
Halles,
e Duke of
Pomerane
& others.
Soldiers Levyed in
Saxony &
e Countryes
adjoyning for
e D:
of Guise.
I am perfectly informed that
e souldiers and Coronels, whose
names I sent yo
r
H. in my last, were levied most in Saxonie,
& the countreis adjoining, & had their paiment from
e Guise.
And if Brunswicke would suffer it, I thinke a quarter of the
countrey would serve in like sort. For the malice of their ministers
hath no kinde of measure, that the common people knowe no otherwise
The malice of
e
Ministers there
against
e Calvinist
as they terme them./
but that they fight against Infidels, when they fight against Calvinists
and thinke the
pope
would not hurt them, if that Calvinists were
gone. While I was at Wolferbeitel, their minister in a sermon before
the Councel, speaking of those that were massacred at
Paris
, ter-
med them a wicked generation, & martyrs of
e divel: wherof
I talked after w
t
some of
e councell. They could not tell me
what other forces have beene levied: because in these quarters by rea-
son of the edictes, they assemble not in troupes, but gett awaye
underhande: nor howe many of the former have passed
e Rhine
for some saye all, & some, but a fewe. But for certaine many have
bin staied by the Electo
r
of Brand
.
e Lantg
.
& Brunsw
.
In
e circle of lowe Saxonie, these be the chiefest of
e Princes, who
by themselves or their deputies must be present. The
Administrator
of Magdeb
.
the
Arch
.
of Breame
, Julius D. of Brunsw
.
Wolfgan
gus D. of Brunsw
.
Wilhelmus D. of Brunsw
.
& Luneb
.
certaine
Dukes of Sax
.
e
Bishop of Halberstat
,
e
D. of Mechelb
.
the
K. of
Denmarke
as D. of Halsatia,
Adolphus D. of Holsatia
, the
Bishop of
Lubecke
fol.193r
Lubecke, & divers other Bishops & Countes, & the cities of Lu-
becke, Hambourghe &c. that it semeth, if the D. of Brunsw
.
will
deale as he maye, his authorite among them being highly estemed,
(for so I am
i
formed) muche good maye come of it. Howbeit he c
o
-
plaineth very often, that we beginne a great deale to late, to sette
suche matters a foote.
S
r
Philip Sidney
hath a very great frinde, one
Andreas Pauli
a
Andreas Pauli his
[pro]mise to excuse
[M]
r
Bodleys not repay-
[ring] to
e D. of Sax
.
his
[M
r
.]/
counsailo
r
to the Duke of Saxonie, who comminge to Wolferbeitel
& understanding of my being, came to diner unto me, & after diner
we conferred together as touching my message, which I commen-
ded unto him, & requested him to favo
r
her Ma
ties
excuse for
not sending to the Electo
r
: for that in sending to & fro muche time
is consumed, and opportunities are lost, & I had hast towardes
Denmarke, & then after must returne. He gave me his promise
to doe it very carefully: but wished in any wise, that the amitie
& frindeshippe betwene her Ma
tie
& his M
r
, might be thorowly
c
o
firmed, & then no dout she might drawe him to all her good
purposes. When I craved to knowe how it might be firmer
His advice touching
e matche betwene
e
Scott
:
K
. &
e
Daughter
[o]f
e K: of Denmarke.
then it was: that is then, said he, to be considered, when occa-
sions are presented. He thought the contrivinge of a matche,
betwene the Scottishe Kinge & a daughter of
e K. of Den-
marcke, would be a gratefull thinge to him, & to all the
Princes heere, & exceeding beneficiall to all protestants
in Christendome. Againe about Michaelmas next, at
Wolferbeitel, the D. of Brunswickes
eldest sonne
shalbe maried
to the D. of Sax
.
elde
second daughter
: where besides many Prin-
ces the K. of Denmarke is looked for. It is possible the D. of
That
e Cloth to be
sent from home to
e
D. of Saxonie. may be
freed from custome./
Sax
.
in respect of that mariage will send for cloth into England,
for whiche Andreas thought it well to take order, that if he send
for any suche, he might be freed of custome: w
c
said he, is a
privilege among Princes: and w
t
all insinuated obsurely, howe
e
D. tooke it ill, that at some time heretofore, he had bin forced to paye
it: for so I understoode him. In all dutifull maner he desired
her Ma
tie
to repute him her servaunt, to be c
o
maunded in any
thinge.
The daye before I departed, one
Jo. Bakelius
phisition to
the D. of Brunsw
.
came unto me to my chamber, suborned
as I take it, by the D. himself, who tolde me, that uppon occa-
sion of talke, the D. did greatly mervel, that o
r
Englishe mar-
chants
fol.193v
An ouverture for
o
r
Merchant
trading
unto Breame & to
leave
Embden
./
had suche a liking to Emden. He thought Breame more conve-
nient, or some other towne therabout: in whiche if they were so
contented the D. himself would pleasure them. For he was a
suter & in hope to gette
e Archb
.
of Breame for his eldest sonne,
Bishop of Halberstat, & besides, the contrey therabout by the
death of
D. Erricke
is fallen into his handes: that if not in Breame
yet in many other places, he could serve their turne very fitly.
Moreover he tolde me, that forasmuche as her Ma
tie
did not
send to the Christening of
Jochim
her godsonne, nor, as he
said, write any letter in answear to
e D. it would be taken
That her Ma
ty
wold
writt to
e Duke an
answeare touching her
Godsonne &c.
very kindly, if her highnes would vouchsafe to remember him
at last, w
t
some token of good will, or sende him c
o
menda-
c
o
ns, and declare her willingnes to see him. Whiche I conjecture
in like maner proceeded from
e D. because he signified unto
me, that he was fully resolved, to send him into England. I
was further informed by him, & by some others of good under-
standing, that there are about many of these Princes many
Principall persons, whose open discourses are altogether Spa-
nishe: that in a maner it is demed, that he hath every where
his pensioners.
Because I am not certaine whether yo
r
H. understand it, I
thought to signifie, that I have seene heere in Lubecke a booke
published in Latin w
t
this title
Incedium Calvinisticum Regis Navarrj
Legatione apud quosdam Imperij status
imperadmodum ad certam religionis ac
Reip. conturbationem procuratum.
The Booke called
Incendi
u
Calvinistic
u
./
No name of autor, nor place,
nor yere
, sette downe, but
e whole
commission & instructions given by the Kinge of Navarra to
Mons
r
Segurius
are contened in it, w
t
the copies of the kinges
letters, & divers letters of divines written to some Princes of Ger-
manie, to deface that legation. I could not gette any heere to
send to yo
r
H. and because it was published 1584 I doe not dout
but yow have seene it, or shall quickly have it in England.
At this very present, there is certaine worde brought to Lubecke,
that
e K. of Denmarke is gone into
Norwaye
: whiche I dout very
muche will staye me from Brunsw
.
longer then I would. For
some give it out, he will continewe there longe, & others make
account of his speedy returne. But I will kepe my course to
Coppenhaven, & there advise me what is best w
t
Mons
r
D'Anoy
fol.194r
Thus howsoever I have erred, ether in tediousnes, or in my maner
of certifieng, or any waye besides, I beseche yo
r
H. most humbly
to impute it rather to any thinge, then to want of diligence or wil-
lingnes to accomplishe my duty:
and therew
t
all I end, and take
my humble leave, desiring God most earnestly, to kepe yo
r
honorable
estate in continuall prosperitie. Lubeck. A
o
1585. May 31.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bouden. Tho. Bodley.
I mette w
t
M
r
Harbert
in Lubecke, of whom I have taken the
copie of a letter, w
c
he hath to deliver to her Ma
tie
from
e
D. of
Prusse
, w
c
will serve me to good purpose, to shewe his affection
& forwardnes to other Princes. For he declareth so his willing-
nes, to joine his forces w
t
her Ma
ties
in a cause of this qualitie,
as if he had bin expressely invited unto it. As farre
as I can conjecture, my going into Denmarke, & returne
againe to Brunswicke, & some aboad in eche place, & some
staye perhaps after, for shipping & winde, maye holde me six
weekes longer in this contrey: that if yo
r
H. have any thing,
to commaund me further, it maye come unto my handes before
I gette awaye from hens. I have taken order w
t
one
Va-
lentine Palmer
a facto
r
for
Alderman Bonde
, & a dweller
in Hambourgh, to convey any letter unto me that shall be sent
me from yo
r
H. w
t
all possible speede: or to returne it
home againe, if I chance to be departed. For I determine
if I be not countermaunded, to returne from Brunswicke
immediatly homewardes, as my course was prescribed in yo
r
H. memoriall.
I send yo
r
H. this letter by one
John Roberts
a marchant
dwelling by
Bassinges Halle
in
London
.
